1 After this the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them two by two ahead of him to every town and place where he was about to go. 2 He told them, “The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field. 3 Go! Do not move around from house to house. 8 “When you enter a town and are welcomed, eat what is offered to you. 9 Heal the sick who are there and tell them, ‘The kingdom of God has come near to you.’ 10 But when you enter a town and are not welcomed, go into its streets and say, 11 ‘Even the dust of your town we wipe from our feet as a warning to you. 29  But he, desiring to justify himself, said to Jesus, “And who is my neighbor?”  30  Jesus replied, “A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he fell among robbers, who stripped him and beat him and departed, leaving him half dead.  31  Now by chance a priest was going down that road, and when he saw him he passed by on the other side.  32  So likewise a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by on the other side.  33  But a Samaritan, as he journeyed, came to where he was, and when he saw him, he had compassion.  34  He went to him and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Expectations around hospitality

The Lord’s Prayer can be broken into 2 sections, the first about establishing our relationship with God and the second about petitioning God, surrendering control over our own life and trusting more in His guidance
What kind of relationship is established between God and us in the first section?
Establishes the relationship between us and God, both with the intimacy of Abba but also the respect and sacredness from hallowed
What is being surrendered/entrusted to God in each petitioning section?
Your kingdom come - petition to see God’s will and kingdom displayed on Earth, entrusting hopes for the future to God’s plans
Daily bread - petition to receive God’s provision for daily/fundamental needs, entrusting provision to God

What obstacle is in the way of each individual that approaches Jesus to follow Him? What does each interaction reveal about what true discipleship to Jesus looks like?
First individual (57-58), assumes he is simply following a rabbi similar to their time. Jesus is warning that he is much greater and does not have a place in the world. His expectation is not correct.
Is a general warning of the conditions and lifestyle a true disciple of Jesus will have - one that lacks comfort and because is focused on an end result not on Earth, will leave those practicing it feeling out of place in the world
Second individual (59-60), more focused on family matters than Jesus. The role of discipleship takes priority over family related manners.
The practice of burying relatives, especially direct family, was one held with some of the highest importance in Jewish/general culture in Jesus’ time.
Jesus’ response demonstrates that true discipleship should hold even greater importance than one’s most sacred/significant family and cultural practices
Third individual (61-62), more focused on his past. Those that look back cannot engage in discipleship. The new has replaced the old.
The purpose of discipleship is to transform us into people who are more like Jesus and therefore more like God, preparing for us life beyond Earth.
Holding too much attention to things and matters that are related to our time on Earth can be a distraction/deterrent from this process of transformation
